MissionCommands.Message: Welcome to the auto-maneuver lesson! In this lesson, we will go deeper into using the Command Module Computer (CMC), and how to orient the spacecraft using the PGNCS (Primary Guidance, Navigation and Control System).

Let us first learn the basics of attitude control of the Command Module. The Stabilization and Control System (SCS) provides a capability for monitoring and controlling the attitude of the spacecraft. It is the backup system for the Primary Guidance, Navigation and Control System (PGNCS).

Today we will learn how to orient the space craft using both the Stabilization and Control System (SCS) and the Primary Guidance, Navigation and Control System (PGNCS, the Command Module Computer basically).
First of all, separate from the S-IVB by pressing the CSM/LV SEP push button.
The CSM is now free from the Launch Vehicle, currently orbiting Earth.
Set the SC CONT switch to SCS. This tells the space craft that the Stabilization and Control System should orient the space craft. Let us power the joystick.

The Stabilization and Control System contains a set of gyros that stores its inertial platform. This is the GDC, Gyro Display Coupler. The GDC is the backup platform. The Inertial Measurement Unity (IMU) is the primary platform.

The Command Module is usually configured so you can see the platform of the Inertial Measurement Unit on FDAI 1, and the Gyro Display Coupler on FDAI 2. It is common to keep the GDC aligned with the IMU in-case the IMU fails.

Rate data from something called the Body Mounted Attitude Gyro (BMAGs) is used by the GDC to calculate the known attitude of the spacecraft relative to the stable orientation stored in the GDC. Two BMAG-assemblies exist, both with the capability to send rate data to the GDC.

The three BMAG switches on panel 1 selects which set of gyros the GDC receives rate data from for a particular axis (roll, pitch, yaw). Let us configure the BMAGs to Att 1/Rate 2 for all axes, meaning the GDC will receive rate data from BMAG 2 while getting attitude data from BMAG 1. This enables for example the SCS rate command mode.

Use the attitude control stick to change the orientation. The SCS is currently configured to an ACCELerate mode. This means that any stick input will fire jets that will accelerate the turning rate of the craft.
Another mode is the Rate Command mode. Let us switch into that now.

Try to deflect the attitude control stick now. If you keep it deflected, the rate will increase up to a point. At this point the jets will stop to fire while the craft drifts. If you release the stick, the craft will stop the rates and maintain the attitude.
The RATE switch on the SCS control panel can be used to set the maximum rate.

Finally, the MIN IMPULSE mode of the SCS can be used for fine attitude control and will, for each deflection of the stick, fire the jet for a minimum impulse. To fire again, the stick needs to be released and deflected again.
Try to use this mode to stop any existing rates, and get familiar with it. Press ROGER to continue with the lesson.

This briefly covers the SCS. As you have seen, the SCS can be used to control the attitude of the craft, and FDAI 2 shows the backup GDC inertial platform. As mentioned, the GDC platform is typically aligned with the IMU, but can be used as a temporarily attitude tool during maneuvers.
Let us take a look at the Primary Guidance, Navigation and Control System.
Set the CMC MODE to FREE.
Then set SC CONT to CMC.
The craft is now under control by the Primary Guidance, Navigation and Control System (PGNCS).
The FREE mode of the CMC is like the ACCEL mode of the SCS. Deflecting the stick will let you accelerate the rates in the direction of the stick deflection. Give it a try, and press ROGER when done.

Set the CMC mode to ATT HOLD, and try to deflect and the attitude control stick. This mode is similar to the SCS RATE COMMAND mode. The rate will build up to a limit as you deflect and hold the stick. Releasing the stick will stop the rates and the CMC will try to hold the attitude.

The Command Module Computer (CMC) is responisble for maintaining a lot of parameters, and is also capable of maneuvering the craft without the need of manual attitude input. But to dive into this, we need to learn more about the computer.

The PGNCS is using onboard systems to point the spacecraft towards a set attitude. To orient, thrusters are fired to start a very slow angular rate to reach the destination orientation. The reason for a slow rate is fuel consumption and weight.
If you need to help it, you can by using DIRECT mode or the SCS and maneuver manually, but always plan your attitude changes, and ensure you always have enough time after time-scaling.
Before firing the thrusters, it is important to verify your attitude with any visual cues you might have, such as the FDAI, windows or the optics. Never trust the attitude blindly.
Let us enable the A/C roll jets.
Having the four A/C roll jets and the four B/D roll jets will let the Digital AutoPilot (DAP) be able to override and select what to use.
Use the VIEW SELECTOR to move over to the COMPUTER DSKY.
VERB 06 is used to read and display a memory location specified by the NOUN.
Some of the NOUNs will display one memory location, and it will be drawn into the first register (R1). There are three registers available.
Some NOUNs will display two memory locations, and they will be drawn into R1 and R2.
Lastly, some NOUNs will render three memory locations into R1, R2 and R3.
NOUN 22 will display the desired angles into R1, R2 and R3. R1 will display roll, R2 will display pitch and R3 will display Yaw.
Start by pressing VERB.
Then press 0.
Then press 6.
Then press NOUN.
Then press 2.
Then press 2.
Lastly, press ENTR.
Each of the numbers have 5 digits, where the last two are used as the decimal part. So if R1 reads 02300, it means roll will be 23.00 degrees. What the five digits represents varies between NOUNs.
Noun 22 displays 00000, 02100, 00000. This means the desired gimbal angles should be set to 0,21,0 degrees relative to the current reference platform.
Please see the Reentry Apollo Flight Manual for a list of all VERBs and NOUNs and how you should read the values displayed.

The Command Module Computer (CMC) can run Programs and Routines to execute functions. We will touch two routines today, R03 to set up the Digital Autopilot (V48E), and R62, the Crew Defined Maneuvering routine (V49E). R62 is the routine id just like P11 is the ascent program id.
We will first directly edit N22 just as an example and learn how to modify values, and then learn how to auto-maneuver using R03 and R62.

Ok, let's learn how to change values by writing into the computer memory. Verb 21 will allow you to insert values into R1, Verb 22 will allow you to insert values into R2 and Verb 23 will allow you to insert values into R3.
You need to insert all the values, including the sign when inserting values.
Since you ran Verb 06 Noun 22, the specified N22 (N stands for Noun) is displayed. We wish to change the YAW value, namely R3, to 180 to auto-maneuver towards this attitude.
We can then use V23 to change R3.
Press VERB.
Press 2.
Press 3.
Press ENTR.

R3 is now blank, and waiting for input. Start by inserting +, followed by 18000, then verify the command follows your intention and is keyed correctly, then press ENTR. Always double-check your command.

When pressing ENTR after that last digit, the value gets inserted into the memory. If you enter something wrong, press CLR to clear and start the entry again. Again, ALWAYS double check before pressing ENTR or PRO!
Are you able to set R2 (pitch) to zero? It shows 21.0 degrees now. Key V22E +00000E to do this (E is ENTR on the DSKY keyboard).
Now, verify that the spacecraft control is given to the Command Module Computer by ensuring SC CONT is set to CMC.
Once we start the auto-maneuver, the spacecraft will maneuver to the attitude relative to the stable reference platform stored in the Inertial Measurement Unit, IMU.

The stable refrence platform is what the attitude indicators (FDAIs) use to show your attitude relative to. If you maneuver so your attitude becomes 0,0,0 on the FDAI, the spacecraft is aligned with the platform stored in the IMU.
In Reentry, I have designed the ORB RATE mode of the ORDEAL to always keep the attitude indicators relative to the Local Vertical Local Horizontal (LVLH).
This means that while the ORDEAL is in ORB RATE, the FDAIs (Attitude Indicators) will snap to an orientation where attitude 0,0,0 points prograde, and attitude 0,0,180 points retrograde.

If you have Simplified ORDEALs enabled (Main Menu -> Settings -> Realism Settings, default on) it will also change the orientation of the IMU, causing maneuvers and attitudes to reflect the ORDEAL setting (they will return back to their original position if you set the ORDEAL to INRTL). I recommend turning this off once you understand how the attitude systems work in the Command Module.
Set the ORDEAL POWER above the left side window to EARTH.
Then set the ORDEAL FDAI 1 to ORB RATE. Notice that the FDAI indicators torque to the LVLH orientation.
Return FDAI 1 back to INRTL. Next we will configure the Digital Autopilot (DAP) using the DAP Data Load routine. This is started using V48.
On the DSKY, press VERB.
Then press 4.
Then press 8.
Verify that the DSKY shows Verb 48, then press ENTR.
Then open the (V48) DAP Data Load checklist from the CSM checklists in the Mission Pad. Get familiar with the checklist then press ROGER.
V04N46 should now be flashing. R1 shows the current DAP setup. Each of the 5 digits in R1 has a meaning, and R1 could be read as ABCDE.
With the current values, assuming R1 shows 31111, A=3,B=1,C=1,D=1,E=1.
A is the spacecraft configuration where 3 means CSM & SIVB. We just separated from the SIVB so this should become 1.
Parameter B and C is used for translations. If B is set to 1, it means that we wish to translate using the thrusters on quad A and C (A/C).

If C is set to 1, it means that we wish to translate using the thrusters on quad B and D (B/D). If both parameters are set to 0, you will not be able to translate. If both are set to 1, you will translate with 4 thrusters. This can be intentional but wastes fuel.
It is recommended to use either A/C (parameter B = 1) or B/D (parameters C = 1). This tells the DAP to translate using two thrusters only.
Each time you are about to translate forward or aft (X-axis), always check the DAP to verify that you have +X translation enabled by having a 1 in either (or both) B and C parameters.

D is the deadband (DB) where 0 will set the deadband to 0.5 degrees and 1 will set it to 5.0 degrees. If set to 5 degrees, the DAP will try to maintain the attitude within 5 degrees. A small DB is more precise but spends more fuel to maintain the accuracy.
E is the rate. Basically, how fast will the spacecraft move towards a set attitude. Low numbers are desired as it consumes less fuel.
We want to set the DAP to 11112. This will be a CSM-only configuration where both A/C and B/D X-translation thrusters are enabled, a deadband (DB) of 5 degrees and a rate of 0.5 degrees/second.
Key V21E +11112 but do not yet press ENTR.
This R1 should show +11112. Verify this and press ENTER to insert the configuration.
R2 also shows you a set of parameters (R2 parameters A, B, C, D, E ).
Parameter A lets you decide if you wish to use the A/C jets or the B/D jets to roll the craft. The rest of the parameters should be set to 1 (still in development). We will set R2 to +01111
Key V22E +01111E, then press ROGER when complete.
Then press PRO. V06 N47 should show. This is the current weight data and needs to be filled in. To get the weights you will need to request the weight data from Mission Control.
Press C on the keyboard to toggle the Circular Function keys. Just below the MDC-2 panel where the CMC/DSKY is located, a circular button named "REQUEST WEIGHTS DATA". Press this to receive the data.
Take a note of the CSM weight (in the Notes section of the Mission Pad for example), we will soon insert it into the CMC using V21E.

The weight might differ but use the number relayed to you. In my case it was 60215 lbs. To do this, Key V21E +60215, then verify the inserted number with the CSM weight you received, and press ENTR to insert it.
The LM weight is bypassed as we selected A=1 in the previous step, so press PRO to proceed to the next, and last step.
In the last step we will need to insert the TVC trim of the SPS. This can be left to zero for now as it's not currently simulated. Hit PRO to end the DAP Setup.
Ok. Now that we have the basics and know how to interact with the CMC, let's give the auto-maneuvering a try using R62 - Crew Defined Maneuvering using V49.
On the DKSY, Key VERB
Then press 4
Then 9
The DSKY should now have 49 in the VERB field. Once verified, press ENTER to start R62.

Let's open the checklist for this too. On the Mission Pad, under the CSM checklists, find the G&C GENERAL -> (V49) CSM Crew Defined Maneuver checklist and open it. Get familiar with it and use it as a reference for the rest of the lesson.
The first thing you will see is the V06N22 displaying. This is the attitude you wish the spacecraft to maneuver towards.
Since we already modified this, we are all good. But you could use V21, V22, V23 or V25 to modify these.
Press PRO to accept these gimbal angles.
Verify that the CMC is in control and the mode is set to AUTO.
This will copy the values of N22 into N18. V50 requests the auto-maneuvering.

Then press PRO to accept the auto-maneuvering. The spacecraft should now start to orient itself towards the desired attitude and the VERB should change from 50 to 06, signaling that the maneuver is in progress.

Notice that the DAP tries to move towards the desired attitude. It uses a slow rate as configured in the DAP setup, and once the desired attitude is reached, it will try to maintain it within the set deadband (5 degrees).

Once the maneuver is complete, V06 will change back to V50. Monitor the FDAI during the maneuver. If it reaches its destination attitude, but does not go to V50, it means the orbital rate or something else prevents this. In this case, press PRO to force it back to V50. Press ROGER when V50 shows, marking the completion of the maneuver.
In summary, V06 will change back to V50 when a maneuver is complete.
You can fine align the maneuver again by pressing PRO when you see V50. This will again change V50 to V06, and return to V50 when complete.
If you are satisfied with the attitude, you can press ENTR during V50 to end the routine. Do this now, you should see the routine completes.
Since the ORDEAL is either OFF or set to INRTL, the FDAIs will display the orientation relative to the IMU (FDAI 1) and GDC (FDAI 2). The platform will stay fixed relative to the stars.

REALISM SETTINGS (Prograde Rotation): There is a realism setting that will disable the automatic prograde rotation simplification of spacecraft bodies (such as the CSM, LM and stages). This will make the attitude behave more realistic and stay fixed relative to the stars (unless you have rates). If this setting is ON (default), the attitude will stay fixed relative to the body it's orbiting (Earth or the Moon), causing the craft to rotate.

REALISM SETTINGS (Simplified ORDEAL): Another setting exists to remove the ORDEAL ORB RATE simplification mode. If disabled, the ORB RATE mode of the ORDEAL will be a visual tool only (more realistic), not affecting the IMU/GDC. This means that when in ORB RATE, the attitude, auto maneuvering, etc, will stay relative to the IMU and not the LVLH. It is recommended to turn this off when you are familiar with the IMU, REFSMMAT, P52 and attitude control.
This concludes the auto-maneuver lesson.
Good job!

Title: Lesson 7 - Automaneuver
Description:
The Computer is used to maneuver the spacecraft. In this lesson, we will take a look at how to do this. We will learn how to read, monitor and write to the Command Module Computer (CMC) memory, and how to orient the spacecraft using the PGNCS. 

We will dive into what the Digital AutoPilot (DAP) parameters are, how they work, and how to set it up. We will also discuss the ORDEAL and the ORB RATE simplification mode that exists in Reentry.

We will then use the DAP to automaneuver to a target attitude.
